instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0A
threads.message:
Received computer from customer. No history, Just stopped charging one day and wont power on. No Liquid damage found.

Was getting 5v 0.3 amps from charger. 

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> was at 2.7V
No short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. 
All other lines on <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> were present and correct.
Surrounding resistors were correct values
Replaced <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>. 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is now 0.7V
Replaced <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> again
Same Results.
injected 3.3V to <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
UB400 Getting hot. 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> was shorted to ground. 
Removed UB400
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is now at 0.3V
Customer decided he now just wants data. Tried Lifeboat connector. nothing shows up. 
Removed L6900 to see if which side the voltage drop is occurring. 
With L6900 Removed. <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_LX</SIGNAL> is back to 3.3V.
Very confused here. No shorts on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>... why is it being pulled down still??
If i inject 3.3V to <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> the and plug in the charger.I get 20V 0A

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0A
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"All other lines on <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> were present and correct."
We prefer exact readings.

Is very important to know exact <DIODE>D6902</DIODE> I/O voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0A
threads.message:
Thank you, pleasure to be here. 

Unfortunately i failed to note the values before replacing the chip but Here are the current Values of <CHIP>U6902</CHIP>:
1: 4.06V
2: 4.27V
3: 0.34V
4:0
5:0
6:0
7:0
8: 4.27V
9: 0.1V
10: 5V

<DIODE>D6902</DIODE>: 
Pin 1: 0V
Pin 2: 5.2V
Pin 3: 4.27

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0A
threads.message:
Was cleaning up some of my soldering around <CHIP>U6902</CHIP>. L6900 split in two when i lifted it off the board. (Never seen an inductor fail like this) Replaced L6900 and All my voltages changed... 

Charger is now 5v 0.03A

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is still low @ 0.89V

<DIODE>D6902</DIODE>:
Pin 1: 0V
Pin 2: 5.2V
Pin 3: 3.65V

1: 4.30V
2: 3.6V
3: 0.89V
4:0
5:0
6:0
7:0
8: 3.6V
9: 0.29V
10: 4.5V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0A
threads.message: Just checked all my LDOs. <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> seems to also be shorted to ground. Only getting 0.3V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> and it has very low resistance to ground. only 37 Ohms. I think the issue is with <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> also. You think i should remove? I really hate the under filled chips so trying to avoid removing lol

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0A
threads.message:
You must compare diode mode readings on LDO lines between all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Then you'll know which chip is bad.

Also need to change <DIODE>D6902</DIODE>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0A
threads.message:
LDO Diode Mode Readings: 

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>: 0.05
<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>: 1.56
UB300: 1.55
UB400: 0 (UB400 Has been removed already due to short on LDO)

So <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> is bad also?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0A
threads.message:
"UB400: 0"
What should we understand?
0= 0.000 (short), or OL (out of range)???

Each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip has 4 LDOs; 1x 3V3, 2x 1V8, 1x 1V1.
<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is very likely bad.
Please check diode mode correctly; red probe connected to ground!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0A
threads.message:
sorry, 0 was meant to be OL. 
I was getting around 0.02 on 3v3 LDO before I removed UB400  

only checked 3v3 LDO. Will recheck all LDO values when I'm back in the shop tomorrow. 

All 4 CD3215s need to be working for 20V right? Meaning, I cant just remove the bad ICs and use the other USB C ports. I have to replace the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> that are bad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0A
threads.message:
SMC needs to talk with all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips before switching to 20V.
You must replace <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and UB400, at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0A
threads.message:
Okay, ordered some CD3215s. 

Removed <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>. replaced <DIODE>D6902</DIODE>. <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is now 3.4V but it is power cycling. Not sure if that is a normal from missing 2 <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> or if there is something else i should be looking for?

Will replace both CD3215s when those arrive and update you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0A
threads.message: Don't waste time until you replace the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0A
threads.message: Sounds good, Will update once those are replaced. Thank you for your help! Much appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0A
threads.message: CD3215s replaced. Board gets 20V and is working perfectly. Thank you again for your help. Can mark this as solved.
